title: Which ancient civilization had the best government? - Quora

response.answer_text: There never has been “the best government” and probably wont ever will be, because no government has maintained authority over its people for more than the Roman’s. Most ancient governments lived and died under their leaders. However, you’d probably like to see a couple of better governments in ancient history. It is a little difficult since most of them were patriarchal, autocratic kings with no restrain. But to be fair there are excellent rulers who did make a good mark on humanity. Ashurbanipal ( he died ca. 630 B.C.) was the last great king of the Assyrian Empire. He was an able soldier and administrator, a scholar, and a patron of art and learning. Although the events of his reign are imperfectly known, and the course of his campaigns cannot be chronologically described. He did establish a massive collection of literary works in huge libraries. Marcus Aurelius was the last of the Five Good Emperors of Rome. His reign (161–180 CE) marked the end of a period of internal tranquility and good government. Unfortunately though after his death the empire quickly descended into civil war. He has symbolized the Golden Age of the Roman Empire for many generations in the West, from his stature as a Philosophy King. However, by fair the most influential and most important, in my view, is: Pericles, he was willing to fight in order to preserve the dignity of Athens and its democracy. He was a good fighter. Despite him having been defeated, he successfully convinced the people that they had won. He preferred to endure hatred and to be unpopular as long as his eyes were focused on the goal. Many of today’s social policies stem from Pericles time during and after the Peloponnesian War. The greatest politician as he did everything to ensure that the sanctity of democracy and the survival of Athens would be held. But that didn't last, with basically the government after his death just going full war mode and losing more of its power than before. Like I said the best government’s don’t exist, they can be close to it but never the absolute.

Although there is no “the best”, but if I was asked to choose one, my vote would go for The Achaemenid empire.  Why? Freedom. it didn’t matter what you believed in, where you came from or who your God was. All you needed to do was to pay taxes, obey the rules and you were safe.Paid workers. According to clay tablets found in Persepolis, one records “One and a half shekels of silver for carpenters making sculptures.” Another details “One jug of wine each to the 74 Syrian laborers working on the columned hall.” Yet another “Two and a half shekels for the carryin gold workers”Banned slavery. In general, mass slavery as a whole has never been practiced by Persians, and in many cases the situation and lives of semi-slaves (prisoners of war) were, in fact, better than those of the commoner. On the whole, in the Achaemenid empire, there was only small number of slaves in relation to the number of free persons and moreover the word used to call a slave was utilized also to express general dependence. Usually, captives were prisoners of war that were recruited from those that rebelled against Achaemenid rule.Fine management. Postal system, Qanats (Water supply system), a fixed taxation and the idea of states and provinces were all Achaemenid inventions.5. This:  Cyrus cylinder, the first declartion of human rights. Thanks for reading, have a good day!

(if 3 votes were gained) each ephor was in power for 1 YEAR and after that THEY COULD NEVER AGAIN BE AT THAT POSITION they created laws and later in meetings votes would take place to continue with the whole processif 3/5 (ephors) agreed the idea would be presented in a public space and spartans would have to simply say “yes” or “no” in case they agree or disagreeif the masses agreed the law would go towards the elders (more on them latter) and they would do the final vote for implementing the lawwhen a king was on a military campaign 2 ephors were with him taking notes on everything the king was doing they had to meet with the next ephors to see if they are behaving elders (gerousia)there were 28 man on They're 60+ based on merit , accomplishment , connections each elder took the power for the reset of he's life and would be replaced once he died they had the power of stopping laws ephors had created in which the masses agreed they formet a jury with the ephors if needed kings could speak to them for important discussions .

I would say ancient Egypt.  Government and religion were inseparable in ancient Egypt. The pharaoh was the head of state and the divine representative of the gods on earth. Religion and government brought order to society through the construction of temples, the creation of laws, taxation, the organization of labour, trade with neighbours and the defence of the country's interests. The pharaoh was assisted by a hierarchy of advisors, priests, officials and administrators, who were responsible for the affairs of the state and the welfare of the people. Ancient Egypt could not have achieved such stability and grandeur without the co-operation of all levels of the population. The pharaoh was at the top of the social hierarchy. Next to him, the most powerful officers were the viziers, the executive heads of the bureaucracy. Under them were the high priests, followed by royal overseers (administrators) who ensured that the 42 district governors carried out the pharaoh's orders. At the bottom of the hierarchy were the scribes, artisans, farmers and labourers. While much of the world was living in primitive conditions, the ancient Egyptians were inventing writing and advancing the sciences of mathematics, medicine and astronomy. They developed ways to measure time and distances , and applied their knowledge to monumental architecture.

I’m going with Achaemenid Persia.  The empire of Darius I The Persian system was quite simple: we don’t care who you are, what you worship or who you’re ruled by. We conquered you by force of arms, you have to pay this much tax in gold or silver each year and supply this many men for our armies. Obey and we’ll protect you come what may, disobey and you will be punished. The system enabled Persia to become one of the most expansive empires of all history. It was copied widely, first by the Greeks in their Successor states, Phonecians of Carthage and later by the Romans and their Res Publica. The downside is that you are left with a hodepodge of cities and settlements whose only connection to you is that you’re a part of their system. They may speak a different languague, in some cases they might follow a religion that may lead them to become disloyal and your armies will be an improvised set of troops that may or may not complement one another. But so long as you have a powerful enough center of your culture and troops and not too many foreign enemies you can sustain this for a very long time indeed.

response.answer_text: Personally, I would have to say Imperial China, because they had civil service exams. The society was based on meritocracy, meaning a lot of important government positions were filled by people who actually deserved to be in those positions… even lowly peasants could be elevated as government officials. While in other civilizations at about the same time period, important positions were often given to noble families on the sole reason that they are of "noble" or "aristocratic" lineage. Another fact is that a lot of these other ancient empires also had a "vassal-overlord relationship" rather than like that of China's more "centralized" rule. Chinese Examination Halls

response.answer_text: To me, with no doubt, Roman empire (republic). Their law is still (!!!!!) Base of most laws even 2000 years later University students at first year studying Roman law. Bureaucracy. Base of any civilization. They invented “res publica”, governing like public thing. Not just for few big dogs on the top. Show me any other idea from other civilizations with bigger influence on modern time. Town organization: Cardo and Decumanus, Forum with temples, savage system, fresh water, etc…. Whenever you turn you have to kick something roman's. That's amazing.
It has been reported that the average Roman’s taxes were about 5% of income. That sounds pretty good to me. But, I would probably have to visit a few for a while to decide which one was best.

That is a hard question to answer, what makes a good government: Stability length it remained on changed individual freedom economic power amount of taxes paid by its citizens How much it interferes in their lives
